section.title: 5.1 Abstract functional blocks
section.para: By abstracting from a (physical) medium to a general 'installation source', (InstSrc) handling different installation sources like 'CD', 'NFS', 'local harddisk', etc. can be generalized. The different installation sources are handled by a installation source manager (InstSrcMgr). For selections, packages, and patches, the installation source is just an additional attribute and does not add to dependency complexity.

Every system has a single installation target (InstTarget), usually a mounted directory (with an rpm database). The installation target is automatically also an installation source 'providing' (already installed) packages to the dependency solver.

The dependency solver has access to the installation source manager which can be queried for data. The different installation sources are handled transparently by the installation source manager. The solver does not have any knowledge about the sources. The solver is controlled from outside (user interface) and can use callbacks/return codes to handle resolving dependencies (conflicts, or-dependencies, etc.).

section.title: 5.2 Installation Source
section.para:
An installation source has general information (data about the source) and detailed information (data about packages) transparently. It's up to the implementation how to handle this data, e.g. by storing cache files for offline access or retrieving packages for detailed data. Splitting the general and detailed information part also on the implementation side leads to a 'package provider' function (PkgProv). Since this is also needed during package installation (in order to actually get the package onto the target system), it is implemented as a separate function block.
An installation source contains
name
version
architecture
dependencies (requires, provides, conflicts, recommends, suggests) e.g Product 'email server 3.1' needs 'basic system 8.1'.
label (descriptive text, in various languages)
language (if package is language specific)
vendor
flags (internal usage)
medium (type of medium, like cd, ftp, etc.)
ID-Code
cache file
MD5 sum (for the cache file) ?
GPG signature
An installation source instance is created for every known installation media. The target system is also regarded as an installation media.

section.title: 5.3 Installation Target
section.para: The package management handles a single installation target. Besides the above mentioned installation source block, an installation target contains a package provider block (getting the package onto the target) and a package installer block (i.e. actually calling rpm). For each needed installation target, one package provider is needed. The notion of 'package' as used above is a bit misleading since the data to be installed on a target might be a package (currently rpm based) or a patch. Both need different installer functionalities.

The installation target provides the following functions
install package
set install flags (i.e. --excludedocs)
delete package
set delete flags
rebuilddb
verify
These are basically the functions 'rpm' is providing on a command line level.

section.title: 5.4 Dependency Solving
section.para: The solver gets a list of installed and a list of requested (selected) packages and resolves conflicts. The solver should be general enough to also handle selections and patches which are represented by similar data.
Solver actions are triggered by the user interface.

section.para: A selection is a set of packages and described by the following attributes

section.title: 5.6 Packages
section.para:
A package is a set of files and described by the following attributes
name
version
architecture
dependencies (requires, provides, conflicts, recommends, suggests)
label (descriptive text, in various languages)
language (if package is language specific)
vendor
flags (internal usage)
MD5 sum (immediately before package installation, cant do this across ftp).
GPG signature

section.title: 5.7 Patches
section.para:
A patch is a set of system changes described by the following attributes
name
version
architecture
dependencies (requires, provides, conflicts, recommends, suggests)
label (descriptive text, in various languages)
vendor
flags (internal usage)
MD5 sum
GPG signature
Set of Text, Script, or packages in any combination.
